title: U.S. National Debt Dashboard
text:
Explanation:
This dashboard visualizes the evolution of the U.S. national debt across presidential administrations from 1993 through 2025. It includes key metrics such as average debt, rate of change, percent change, and debt trajectory over time. Economic events are annotated on the timeline. The dashboard is interactive, allowing users to explore the data by administration and year. The data is sourced from the U.S. Department of the Treasury and the Congressional Budget Office.

Panel 1 ‚Äì Average Debt (USD) by administration:

Debt levels steadily increase over time, regardless of party.
Democratic administrations (blue bars) and Republican administrations (solid red) both show growth.
Trump‚Äôs second term (2025‚Äì2028) is represented with a striped red bar, indicating a projected administration.
The highest average debt is seen during the projected Trump (2nd Term), reflecting cumulative debt and continued fiscal expansion.



Panel 2 ‚Äì Average Debt Slope (Rate of Change in Debt)

This shows the average annual increase in total debt for each administration.
The slope generally increases from Clinton through Trump (1st Term).
A steep increase under Biden, indicating high borrowing during the COVID recovery period.
A sharp drop in slope for Trump (2nd Term), likely due to limited available data (only 2025 included so far).



Panel 3 ‚Äì Average Debt Percent Change (%)

Shows relative year-over-year growth in debt.
High percent change under Obama (1st Term) and Trump (1st Term) due to post-recession and pandemic spending.
The percentage declines in recent years, as the debt base becomes much larger.
The Trump (2nd Term) bar drops to 0% ‚Äî this reflects only one data point (2025) being available so far.



Panel 4 ‚Äì Debt Trajectory Over Time (1993 - 2025)

The debt curve is exponential, accelerating particularly after:

2008 (Great Recession)


2020 (COVID-19 Pandemic)

Vertical dashed lines mark major economic events:

üìâ 2001: Dot-com Bust


üí• 2008: Great Recession


‚ö†Ô∏è 2011: Debt Ceiling Crisis


ü¶† 2020: COVID-19


There is no sign of debt deceleration ‚Äî even as crises resolve, debt continues to rise.

title: U.S. National Debt Dashboard
text:
Key Takeaways:

National debt is not strictly tied to political party, but economic events (recessions, crises) are major inflection points.
The Trump (2nd Term) projection highlights the need for caution when interpreting future metrics based on partial-year data.
Long-term debt growth has outpaced GDP growth in many years, signaling potential sustainability challenges.

title: U.S. National Debt Dashboard
text:
National Debt vs.¬†National Deficit

National Deficit

The deficit is the shortfall in a single fiscal year.
It occurs when the government spends more money than it collects in revenue (mainly from taxes).
If the government takes in less than it spends, it runs a deficit.
If it takes in more, it runs a surplus.



National Debt

The national debt is the total amount of money the government owes over time.
It‚Äôs the sum of all past deficits, minus any surpluses.
When the government runs a deficit, it borrows money‚Äîusually by issuing Treasury bonds‚Äîand this borrowing adds to the national debt.

Think of it this way:
Deficit = the amount you overspent this year
Debt = your total credit card balance over time

Economic Performancy by political party
A frequently cited academic paper is:
‚ÄúPresidents and the Economy: A Forensic Investigation‚Äù Alan S. Blinder & Mark W. Watson, American Economic Review (2016) DOI: 10.1257/aer.20140913

Summary of Their Findings (1947‚Äì2013):

GDP Growth: 1.8 percentage points faster under Democratic presidents on average.
Job Growth: Faster under Democrats.
Unemployment: Fell more under Democrats, rose under Republicans on average.
Stock Market: Higher returns under Democrats.
Inflation: Slightly lower under Democrats.
Consumer Confidence: Significantly higher under Democrats.


But here‚Äôs the kicker: Blinder and Watson concluded that these differences are statistically significant but not entirely due to policy. Much of the performance seems to come down to ‚Äúgood luck‚Äù, such as oil shocks, international crises, and business cycles.

title: U.S. National Debt Dashboard
text:
Nuances

Congress Matters Too: Many economic policies require Congressional approval. Mixed-party control can blur outcomes.
Lag Effects: Some economic results stem from policies of previous administrations.
External Shocks: Oil embargoes (1970s), dot-com bust (2000), Great Recession (2008), COVID-19 (2020) heavily affect economic metrics.

Blinder & Watson (2016): ‚ÄúPresidents and the U.S. Economy: An Econometric Exploration‚Äù ‚Äî American Economic Review. DOI: 10.1257/aer.20140913
BLS: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics ‚Äî Monthly jobs and unemployment data. bls.gov
CBO: Congressional Budget Office ‚Äî Historical budget data and deficit/surplus reports. cbo.gov
U.S. Treasury: Historical federal deficit and debt data. fiscaldata.treasury.gov
BEA: Bureau of Economic Analysis ‚Äî Business investment and GDP breakdowns. bea.gov
CEPR & EPI: Center for Economic and Policy Research, Economic Policy Institute ‚Äî Wage inequality studies. cepr.net, epi.org
JPMorgan / Forbes: Analyses on market returns by party. E.g., Forbes
